The future of abortion in America may look a lot like the past. Listen to the full season of Slow Burn: Roe v. Wade now. https://t.co/cnrxWx0NzM

Supreme Court Justice Harry Blackmun wrote Roe v. Wade after months of research and deliberation. His opinion immediately received fierce backlash, and he became an unlikely defender of abortion rights after 1973. He stuck by his opinion until the end. https://t.co/7O960hOosS https://t.co/X53DG5J5g2

In the 1970s, two-thirds of Americans supported liberalizing abortion laws. So how did the anti-abortion movement become such a powerhouse? Its success can be traced back to the playbook of a pair of right-to-life activists. https://t.co/gzP04U7UUs

In 1968, Ann Hill got an illegal abortion. The harrowing experience radicalized her, and she served as a lawyer on a case that succeeded in overturning Connecticut’s abortion ban. She thinks there are lessons to be learned from her experience. https://t.co/9uCAi02uhN https://t.co/GucY0GGZVE

If you’re trying to understand what just happened, listen to the latest season of Slow Burn on Roe v. Wade. It explains what abortion rights looked like before Roe, how the pro-life movement formed, and how SCOTUS tried to solve the issue once and for all. https://t.co/cnrxWx0NzM

Before Roe, some people had access to safe abortions, while others risked their lives to get care. Shirley Wheeler, who was thrown in jail and prosecuted for manslaughter after an illegal abortion, made clear the toll of criminalizing abortion. https://t.co/O2uwXWNzDq https://t.co/oDXjRC6SjU

What will a post-Roe America look like? The decision raises a slew of urgent legal and social questions that will now be debated on the local, state, and federal levels. https://t.co/pC1YpNmy1G https://t.co/d487SLnjuE

Justice Samuel Alito’s opinion in the Dobbs case rejects the precedent set by Roe nearly 50 years ago. His writing reflects the conservative movement’s fervent opposition to abortion. https://t.co/pC1YpNmy1G https://t.co/9Xh8BX6bGq
The Supreme Court’s decision to overrule Roe v. Wade will have immediate and widespread repercussions across the U.S., writes @mjs_DC. https://t.co/pC1YpNmy1G https://t.co/0FuOKXmO85

The boldest voices in the pro-life movement want something much worse, writes @Dahlialithwick. “We will also continue to see draconian punishments meted out to women who miscarry, who use drugs during pregnancy, who attempt suicide while pregnant." https://t.co/5Z9RaWB2io
In one state, doctors were already turning away women who were miscarrying. This will be America’s new normal. https://t.co/3Rey0FeuyN

The Supreme Court has overturned Roe v. Wade in a ruling by Justice Samuel Alito. @mjs_DC writes, “Although Alito suggests that his decision will simply revert the nation back to its pre-Roe status quo, that is a fantasy.” https://t.co/pC1YpNmy1G https://t.co/wWPMUFbPs7

In a post-Roe America, the future of abortion will not be in doctor’s offices and clinics. As @c_cauterucci writes, “the abortion pill will be more essential to American self-determination than it ever was when abortion was legal in all 50 states.”
https://t.co/Z7kb4IdP0v
Learn more about medication abortion in this story by @c_cauterucci: https://t.co/Z7kb4IemQ3
How are some states now targeting medication abortion? https://t.co/oZpsJAr3IH https://t.co/HHOoIRJ55s

Is abortion now illegal? No, not nationwide. But many states have bans or restrictions that were designed to go into effect as soon as Roe was overturned. https://t.co/oZpsJAr3IH https://t.co/hYBb6scyoO
